Award.AwardTitle: Honorary Symposium for Prof. K.K. Chawla: Fibers, Foams and Composites Science and Engineering
Award.AbstractNarration: The Honorary Symposium for Prof. K.K. Chawla: Fibers, Foams, and Composites - Science and Engineering, to be held at the Materials Science & Technology 2011 Conference and Exhibition (MS&T 11) October 16-20, 2011 in Columbus, OH, was selected by the MS&T programming committee as the only symposium at MS&T 2011 to be designated as an "honorary" symposium. It is a tribute to Prof. Krishan Chawla's longstanding and distinguished contributions to all types of composite materials. The MS&T conference is expected to have an attendance of approximately 3,500, including participants from the Americas, Europe, and Asia. All types of research institutions (academia, government, and industrial research laboratories) will be represented. The symposium will bring together researchers in an informal setting with ample time for discussion and interaction. The annual MS&T conference is organized cooperatively by four leading materials societies, including The Minerals Metals & Materials Society (TMS), Association for Iron and Steel Technologies (AIST), American Society for Metals (ASM) International, and The American Ceramic Society (ACerS), bringing together professional members of the materials community to interact. This international symposium will involve experts who will present the latest developments in processing, interfaces, mechanical behavior, and properties of composites and foams. Participation by students will be encouraged, in order to help foster future generations of composites scientists and engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The “Professor K. K. Chawla Honorary Symposium on Fibers, Foams and Composites: Science and Engineering” was held at the Materials Science & Technology 2011 (MS&T'11) Conference and Exhibition in Columbus, OH, 16-20 October 2011, and was partially supported by NSF funding. At this symposium, a total of 37 talks were delivered over six sessions, spanning three and one half days. Many of these talks were by invited experts on fibers, foams, or composite materials.

The intent of this specific international symposium was to bring together experts in the field to present the latest developments in the various structures, properties, and applications of fibers, foams and composites. In this context, the term fiber refers primarily to materials that are very thin and long and are embedded into other materials to enhance their strength and other physical properties. The term foam refers to solid materials such as a ceramic or metal that is extremely porous. These light-weight structures have uses in many fields including the medical field. Finally, a composite material is comprised of two or more classes of material (such as ceramic and metal) that are combined in such a way as to produce unique and desirable properties.

Since the Materials Science & Technology Conference and Exhibit is coordinated by four different materials societies, the occurrence of this symposium at this particular conference also exposed other researchers, industrial participants, and students within the larger materials community to challenging topics in composites and foams.  Participation by students was also encouraged, in order to help foster future generations of composites scientists and engineers. The six sessions provided a wide variety of technical topics and were focused on a variety of different types of composite materials, foams, and fibers.
